original.title: Book II: The Ring of Gyges
original.preview: Glaucon: Socrates, do you wish really to persuade us, or only to seem to have persuaded us, that to be just is always better than to be unjust?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Socrates, do you wish really to persuade us, or only to seem to have persuaded us, that to be just is always better than to be unjust?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I should wish really to persuade you, if I could.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Then you certainly have not succeeded. Let me ask you now: How would you arrange goods—are there not some which we welcome for their own sakes, and independently of their consequences, as, for example, harmless pleasures and enjoyments, which delight us at the time, although nothing follows from them?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I agree in thinking that there is such a class.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Is there not also a second class of goods, such as knowledge, sight, health, which are desirable not only in themselves, but also for their results?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And would you not recognize a third class, such as gymnastic, and the care of the sick, and the physician's art; also the various ways of money-making—these do us good but we regard them as disagreeable; and no one would choose them for their own sakes, but only for the sake of some reward or result which flows from them?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There is this third class also. But why do you ask?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Because I want to know in which of the three classes you would place justice?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In the highest class—among those goods which he who would be happy desires both for their own sake and for the sake of their results.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Then the many are of another mind; they think that justice is to be reckoned in the troublesome class, among goods which are to be pursued for the sake of rewards and of reputation, but in themselves are disagreeable and rather to be avoided.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I know that this is their manner of thinking, and that this was the thesis which Thrasymachus was maintaining just now, when he censured justice and praised injustice. But I am too stupid to be convinced by him.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I wish that you would hear me as well as him, and then I shall see whether you and I agree. For Thrasymachus seems to me, like a snake, to have been charmed by your voice sooner than he ought to have been; but to my mind the nature of justice and injustice have not yet been made clear.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Setting aside their rewards and results, I want to know what they are in themselves, and how they inwardly work in the soul. If you please, then, I will revive the argument of Thrasymachus.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And first I will speak of the nature and origin of justice according to the common view of them. Secondly, I will show that all men who practise justice do so against their will, of necessity, but not as a good. And thirdly, I will argue that there is reason in this view, for the life of the unjust is after all better far than the life of the just.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Indeed I do approve of your proposal; nor can I imagine any theme about which a man of sense would oftener wish to converse.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I am delighted to hear you say so, and shall begin by speaking, as I proposed, of the nature and origin of justice.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: They say that to do injustice is, by nature, good; to suffer injustice, evil; but that the evil is greater than the good. And so when men have both done and suffered injustice and have had experience of both, not being able to avoid the one and obtain the other, they think that they had better agree among themselves to have neither.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Hence there arise laws and mutual covenants; and that which is ordained by law is termed by them lawful and just. This they affirm to be the origin and nature of justice—it is a mean or compromise, between the best of all, which is to do injustice and not be punished, and the worst of all, which is to suffer injustice without the power of retaliation.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Now that those who practise justice do so involuntarily and because they have not the power to be unjust will best appear if we imagine something of this kind: having given both to the just and the unjust power to do what they will, let us watch and see whither desire will lead them.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The liberty which we are supposing may be most completely given to them in the form of such a power as is said to have been possessed by Gyges the ancestor of Croesus the Lydian. According to the tradition, Gyges was a shepherd in the service of the king of Lydia.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: There was a great storm, and an earthquake made an opening in the earth at the place where he was feeding his flock. Amazed at the sight, he descended into the opening, where, among other marvels, he beheld a hollow brazen horse, having doors.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: At which he stooping and looking in saw a dead body of stature, as appeared to him, more than human, and having nothing on but a gold ring; this he took from the finger of the dead and reascended.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Now the shepherds met together, according to custom, that they might send their monthly report about the flocks to the king; into their assembly he came having the ring on his finger, and as he was sitting among them he chanced to turn the collet of the ring inside his hand, when instantly he became invisible to the rest of the company and they began to speak of him as if he were no longer present.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: He was astonished at this, and again touching the ring he turned the collet outwards and reappeared; he made several trials of the ring, and always with the same result—when he turned the collet inwards he became invisible, when outwards he reappeared.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Whereupon he contrived to be chosen one of the messengers who were sent to the court; where as soon as he arrived he seduced the queen, and with her help conspired against the king and slew him, and took the kingdom.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Suppose now that there were two such magic rings, and the just put on one of them and the unjust the other; no man can be imagined to be of such an iron nature that he would stand fast in justice.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No man would keep his hands off what was not his own when he could safely take what he liked out of the market, or go into houses and lie with any one at his pleasure, or kill or release from prison whom he would, and in all respects be like a God among men.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Then the actions of the just would be as the actions of the unjust; they would both come at last to the same point. And this we may truly affirm to be a great proof that a man is just, not willingly or because he thinks that justice is any good to him individually, but of necessity.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: For all men believe in their hearts that injustice is far more profitable to the individual than justice, and he who argues as I have been supposing, will say that they are right.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: If you could imagine any one obtaining this power of becoming invisible, and never doing any wrong or touching what was another's, he would be thought by the lookers-on to be a most wretched idiot, although they would praise him to one another's faces, and keep up appearances with one another from a fear that they too might suffer injustice.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Heavens! my dear Glaucon, how energetically you polish them up for the decision, first one and then the other, as if they were two statues.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I do my best. And now that we know what they are like there is no difficulty in tracing out the sort of life which awaits either of them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Socrates, you do not suppose that there is nothing more to be urged?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Why, what else is there?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: The strongest point of all has not been even mentioned.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well, then, according to the proverb, 'Let brother help brother'—if he fails in any part do you assist him; although I must confess that Glaucon has already said quite enough to lay me in the dust, and take from me the power of helping justice.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Nonsense. But let me add something more: There is another side to Glaucon's argument about the praise and censure of justice and injustice, which is equally required in order to bring out what I believe to be his meaning.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Parents and tutors are always telling their sons and their wards that they are to be just; but why? not for the sake of justice, but for the sake of character and reputation; in the hope of obtaining for him who is reputed just some of those offices, marriages, and the like.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: The universal voice of mankind is always declaring that justice and virtue are honourable, but grievous and toilsome; and that the pleasures of vice and injustice are easy of attainment, and are only censured by law and opinion.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They say also that honesty is for the most part less profitable than dishonesty; and they are quite ready to call wicked men happy, and to honour them both in public and private when they are rich or in any other way influential, while they despise and overlook those who may be weak and poor, even though acknowledging them to be better than the others.

modern.title: Book II: The Ring Thing
modern.preview: Glaucon: Socrates, do you actually want to convince us that being just is always better than being unjust, or are you just trying to look like you convinced us?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Socrates, do you actually want to convince us that being just is always better than being unjust, or are you just trying to look like you convinced us?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I'd really want to convince you, if I could.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Well then you totally failed. Let me ask you this: How would you categorize different types of good things? Like, aren't there some things we want just for themselves—harmless pleasures that feel good in the moment even though nothing comes from them?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yeah, I think there's definitely that category.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And then there's a second category, like knowledge, sight, health—things that are good both for themselves AND for what they lead to?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And wouldn't you also recognize a third category, like going to the gym, taking care of sick people, being a doctor, or various ways of making money—stuff that's good for us but we find it unpleasant? Like, no one would choose them for their own sake, only for the rewards that come from them?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yeah, there's that third category too. But why are you asking?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Because I want to know which of these three categories you'd put justice in.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In the highest category—among those good things that anyone who wants to be happy would want both for their own sake and for their results.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Well most people disagree with you. They think justice belongs in the annoying category—stuff you pursue for the rewards and reputation, but that's actually unpleasant and you'd rather avoid if you could.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I know that's how they think, and that was Thrasymachus's whole argument when he was criticizing justice and praising injustice. But I'm too dense to be convinced by him.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I want you to hear me out too, and then we'll see if we agree. Because I think Thrasymachus gave up too easily when you charmed him with your words—but I don't think the nature of justice and injustice has actually been made clear yet.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Setting aside rewards and consequences, I want to know what they actually ARE, and how they work inside someone's soul. So let me revive Thrasymachus's argument, if that's okay.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: First, I'll explain the nature and origin of justice according to popular opinion. Second, I'll show that everyone who acts justly does it against their will, out of necessity, not because it's good. And third, I'll argue this makes sense because an unjust life is way better than a just one.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I definitely approve of your proposal. I can't think of any topic a reasonable person would want to discuss more often.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Great to hear! So let me start with the nature and origin of justice, like I said.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: People say that doing injustice is naturally good, but suffering injustice is bad—and the bad outweighs the good. So when people have experienced both doing and suffering injustice, and can't avoid one while getting the other, they figure it's better to agree to have neither.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's where laws and mutual agreements come from. What's ordained by law gets called 'lawful' and 'just.' This is supposed to be justice's origin and nature—it's a compromise between the best scenario (doing injustice without punishment) and the worst (suffering injustice without being able to retaliate).

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The best way to show that people only act justly because they don't have the power to be unjust is to imagine this: give both just and unjust people the power to do whatever they want, then watch where their desires lead them.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: We can give them complete freedom through a power like what Gyges supposedly had—you know, the ancestor of Croesus. The story goes that Gyges was a shepherd working for the king of Lydia.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: There was this massive storm and earthquake that cracked open the ground where he was grazing his flock. Amazed, he climbed down into the opening and found all these crazy things, including a hollow bronze horse with doors.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: He looked inside and saw a dead body that seemed larger than human, wearing nothing but a gold ring. He took the ring from the corpse and climbed back out.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The shepherds had their monthly meeting to report to the king about the flocks. He showed up wearing the ring, and while he was sitting with them, he accidentally turned the setting of the ring toward his palm—and instantly became invisible! The others started talking about him like he wasn't there anymore.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: He was shocked and experimented with the ring. Same result every time—turn the setting inward and he'd disappear, turn it outward and he'd reappear.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: So he arranged to become one of the messengers sent to the royal court. As soon as he got there, he seduced the queen, and together they plotted against the king, killed him, and took over the kingdom.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Now imagine there were two such magic rings—one for a just person and one for an unjust person. No one could possibly be so rigid that they'd stick to justice.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No one would keep their hands off other people's stuff when they could safely take whatever they wanted from the market, sneak into houses and sleep with whoever they wanted, kill or free prisoners at will—basically be like a god among humans.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The 'just' person would act exactly like the unjust one. They'd end up in the same place. And this proves that people are only just out of necessity, not because they think justice is actually good for them personally.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Deep down, everyone believes injustice is way more profitable for individuals than justice. And anyone making my argument would say they're right.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: If someone got this invisibility power and never did anything wrong or took what wasn't theirs, people watching would think they're a complete idiot—though they'd praise them to their faces out of fear that they might suffer injustice themselves.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Wow! Glaucon, you're really polishing up both sides of this argument like they're statues or something.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I'm doing my best. And now that we know what they're like, it's easy to trace out what kind of life each one would have.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Socrates, you don't think there's nothing more to add to this argument, do you?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What else is there?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: The strongest point hasn't even been mentioned yet.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well then, 'let brother help brother' as they say—if Glaucon's missing something, you help him out. Though I have to say Glaucon has already said enough to completely destroy me and take away any power I had to defend justice.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Nonsense. But let me add something: There's another side to Glaucon's argument about how people praise and criticize justice and injustice that we need to bring out.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Parents and teachers are always telling their kids to be just—but why? Not for justice's sake, but for reputation and character. They're hoping that someone with a reputation for justice will get good jobs, marriages, and all that stuff.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Everyone's always saying justice and virtue are honorable, but difficult and exhausting, while the pleasures of vice and injustice are easy to get and only criticized by law and public opinion.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They also say honesty usually pays less than dishonesty. They're totally willing to call wicked people happy and honor them publicly and privately when they're rich or influential, while they despise and ignore people who are weak and poor, even when they admit those people are better human beings.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: But here's the most extraordinary thing about how they talk about virtue and the gods: they say the gods give disaster and misery to many good people, while giving good fortune and happiness to wicked people.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: And these fortune-tellers go to rich people's houses convincing them they have divine power to fix someone's sins or their ancestors' sins through sacrifices and rituals, with parties and feasts.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They promise to hurt enemies, whether they're just or unjust, for a small fee, using magic and spells to supposedly control heaven itself.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: When young people hear all this about virtue and vice, and how gods and humans view them, how do you think their minds will be affected? The smart ones who pick up everything?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They'll probably think: 'Should I get ahead through justice or through lies and cheating?' Because what people say is: if I'm actually just but not seen as just, there's no benefit—just obvious pain and loss.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: But if I'm unjust yet get a reputation for justice, I'm promised a perfect life. Since appearance controls truth and rules over happiness, I should focus on appearances.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: So knowing all this, how can someone with any intelligence, looks, status, or wealth want to respect justice? How can they not laugh when they hear justice being praised?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: The problem is this: no one has ever properly described what justice and injustice actually do in someone's soul, by themselves, whether gods and humans see it or not.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: No one has shown that injustice is the greatest evil a soul can contain, and justice the greatest good. If everyone had said this from the beginning and convinced us from childhood, we wouldn't need to watch each other to prevent injustice—everyone would guard themselves, afraid of harboring the worst possible evil.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: This is what Thrasymachus and others say about justice and injustice. They're totally twisting their real power, but I've stated their case as strongly as possible because I want to hear the opposite from you.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Don't just show us that justice is better than injustice—show us what each one does to the person who has it that makes one bad and the other good, whether gods and humans notice or not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I've always admired you two, but hearing this I'm absolutely delighted. That poem about you after the battle of Megara got it right: 'Sons of Ariston, divine offspring of an illustrious hero.'

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There's something truly divine about being able to argue so well for injustice while remaining unconvinced by your own arguments. I can tell from your character that you don't actually believe what you're saying.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But that makes this harder for me. I'm stuck between two problems: I feel unequal to the task, since you weren't satisfied with my answer to Thrasymachus. But I can't refuse to help either—it would be wrong to hear justice attacked and not defend it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: This inquiry is serious and will require really good vision. Since we're not the brightest, I think we should try a different method.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: It's like if someone with bad eyesight was asked to read small letters from far away, but then someone noticed the same letters written larger somewhere else. Reading the big letters first would be lucky, right?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True, but how does this apply to our question?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Justice can exist in an individual person and also in a state. And a state is larger than a person, right?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So in the larger thing, justice might be more obvious and easier to see. I suggest we look for justice in the state first, then in the individual, going from bigger to smaller.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's an excellent idea.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If we imagine a state being created, we can watch justice and injustice being created too.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Probably.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When the state is complete, we might find what we're looking for more easily. Should we try to build one? It's going to be a big project.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I've thought about it, and I really want you to go ahead.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A state exists because people have needs. No one is self-sufficient—we all have many needs. Can you imagine any other reason for a state to exist?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: No other reason.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So people take helpers for different purposes, and when these partners and helpers live together, we call that group of inhabitants a state.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And they trade with each other, giving and receiving, thinking the exchange will benefit them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then let's start building our imaginary state. The real creator is necessity—the mother of invention.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The first and most important necessity is food—the condition for life and existence.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Second is shelter, third is clothing and similar needs.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So how will our city supply this demand? We'll need a farmer, a builder, a weaver. Should we add a shoemaker or other providers for physical needs?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Makes sense.
